title: Scripture as the word of God

children.title: Scripture
children.comment: The biblical writings, inspired by the Holy Spirit, have been entrusted to the church to remind it of the central teachings of the gospel, to guard it from error and to enable it to grow into holiness. The church is required to be obedient to Scripture and revere it as the Word of God.

children.title: Scripture, inspiration and authority of
children.comment: Those writings that are acknowledged to be the word of God to be revered as issuing from him and as having his authority.

children.title: Recognition of a body of sacred writings

primaryrefs.comment: Jesus Christ frequently appealed to the OT as a recognised sacred corpus, with the expression ``it is written''.

children.title: The authority of Scripture recognised in the OT
The authority of Scripture recognised in the NT
Jesus Christ claims scriptural authority for his own words
Scripture, purpose of
children.comment: Scripture has been given by God to lead people to faith and salvation. Through Scripture believers are nurtured in faith and led to spiritual maturity.

children.title: Scripture is intended to lead people to salvation
Scripture is intended to lead believers to maturity in faith
By its record of God's promises
Scripture is essential for spiritual growth and maturity
Scripture, understanding
children.comment: God intends his word to be understood and has provided the directions and means for understanding it.

children.title: Scripture is intended to be clearly understood
It is accessible to ordinary people
Some sections are difficult to understand
God has prescribed the way to understand Scripture
Assistance in understanding through the Holy Spirit
Assistance in understanding through ministers of the word
Scripture, sufficiency of
children.comment: Scripture is presented as being of itself sufficient for faith and for life.

children.title: The NT records the completion and fulfilment of the OT
Warnings against turning from, or adding to, the apostolic gospel, as set forth in Scripture
Descriptions of Scripture point to its sufficiency

children.comment: Those writings that are acknowledged to be the word of God to be revered as issuing from him and as having his authority.

children.title: Recognition of a body of sacred writings

primaryrefs.comment: Jesus Christ frequently appealed to the OT as a recognised sacred corpus, with the expression ``it is written''.

children.title: The authority of Scripture recognised in the OT
The authority of Scripture recognised in the NT
Jesus Christ claims scriptural authority for his own words
Scripture, purpose of
children.comment: Scripture has been given by God to lead people to faith and salvation. Through Scripture believers are nurtured in faith and led to spiritual maturity.

children.title: Scripture is intended to lead people to salvation
Scripture is intended to lead believers to maturity in faith
By its record of God's promises
Scripture is essential for spiritual growth and maturity
Scripture, understanding
children.comment: God intends his word to be understood and has provided the directions and means for understanding it.

children.title: Scripture is intended to be clearly understood
It is accessible to ordinary people
Some sections are difficult to understand
God has prescribed the way to understand Scripture
Assistance in understanding through the Holy Spirit
Assistance in understanding through ministers of the word
Scripture, sufficiency of
children.comment: Scripture is presented as being of itself sufficient for faith and for life.

children.title: The NT records the completion and fulfilment of the OT
Warnings against turning from, or adding to, the apostolic gospel, as set forth in Scripture
Descriptions of Scripture point to its sufficiency
beatitudes, the
children.comment: The blessings pronounced by Jesus Christ in the Sermon on the Mount on those whose lives exhibit particular characteristics or qualities. These contrast sharply with popular values and outlooks.

cschildren.title: The poor in spirit
Those who mourn
The meek
Those who hunger after righteousness
The merciful
The pure in heart
The peacemakers
The righteous who suffer persecution

children.title: Book of the Covenant
children.comment: The customary designation given to the code of law in Ex 20:22-23:33, but it may also have included the Ten Commandments (Ex 20:2-17).

cschildren.title: Moses reads the Book of the Covenant to the Israelites

seealsos.comment: The Book of the Covenant is the oldest, extant codification of Israelite law, where human values are constantly elevated over material ones. It can be argued that each section of the code is a further exposition of one of the Ten Commandments, giving specific case laws.

cschildren.title: Josiah reads the rediscovered Book of the Covenant to the people of Judah

seealsos.comment: This reference to the Book of the Covenant applies either to all or part of the book of Deuteronomy, or to the entire Mosaic Law.

children.title: Book of the Law
children.comment: A documentary form of the Law placed beside the ark of the covenant as a reminder to Israel of her covenant obligation. It was rediscovered and applied during the reign of King Josiah of Judah and read publicly by Ezra after the rebuilding of the walls of Jerusalem.

cschildren.title: The Book of the Law was written by Moses

primaryrefs.comment: The book in question could be the material now included as chapters 1-30, although some scholars suggest it might refer to the material now included as chapters 12-26.

cschildren.title: The Book of the Law was passed from Moses to Joshua
The Book of the Law during the monarchy
The Book of the Law was rediscovered and applied in Josiah's reign

primaryrefs.comment: A reference to part or all of Deuteronomy or possibly the entire Pentateuch (Genesis to Deuteronomy).

cschildren.title: The Book of the Law was read publicly by Ezra
Paul refers to the Book of the Law

primaryrefs.comment: Paul is teaching that justification is by faith.

children.title: numbers, significance of
children.comment: Numbers appear frequently in Scripture and in a variety of contexts. Occasionally they have a special theological significance.

children.title: numbers, 1-2
children.comment: The number one is often associated with the uniqueness of God and also with the unity between God and his people. The number two is used in a variety of contexts.

children.title: One who acts on behalf of others
Christians are to be one in Jesus Christ Jesus Christ
Christians are to be one in spirit
Two of every kind in the ark

secondaryrefs.comment: the prodigal son and his brother

children.title: Teams of two: Jesus Christ's disciples
Teams of two: Paul and his colleagues
Two tablets of the Ten Commandments
numbers, 3-5
children.comment: The number three, primarily associated with the doctrine of the Trinity, is also associated with periods of specially significant divine activity (e.g., ``on the third day''). Four and five have a variety of associations.

children.title: The triad of faith, hope and love

primaryrefs.comment: Three days is a common period, often indicating the length of a journey or a period leading to a critical point.

children.title: Jesus Christ was raised after three days

secondaryrefs.comment: the three mighty men among David's chiefs

primaryrefs.comment: NIV footnote.

children.title: Four representing the complete created order

primaryrefs.comment: This symbol is probably based on the four points of the compass.

children.title: Four living creatures
children.precomment: The four living creatures in Ezekiel and Revelation represent the whole animate creation glorifying God:

children.title: Four kingdoms
children.precomment: Human history before the coming of God's kingdom is spanned by four great human kingdoms, often understood to refer to the empires of Babylon, Persia, Greece and Rome:

children.title: numbers, 6-10
children.comment: The number seven is especially associated with completeness and perfection.  The number ten is occasionally used as a symbol of completeness.  Other numbers have a variety of associations.

children.title: The world was created in six days
Human work is to be limited to six days a week
Human work restricted to six-year periods
The seventh day is a day of rest
The seventh year symbolises rest and freedom
The Feast of Weeks, or Pentecost, comes seven weeks after the firstfruits of the harvest
Seven times indicates a completed action
Eighth day as the day of circumcision
Eighth day as the end of major festivals
Jesus Christ died at the ninth hour
Ten as a symbol of completeness
Ten days as an approximate period
numbers, 11-99
children.comment: Significant numbers include twelve, often associated with the full number of God's people, and multiples of ten, especially forty and seventy.

children.title: The church symbolised as twelve tribes

seealsos.comment: The term ``the Twelve'' is used here even though only eleven disciples remained at the time referred to.

children.title: Passover on the fourteenth day of the first month
Passover on the fourteenth day of the second month
Genealogy of Jesus Christ in spans of fourteen generations
Twenty as the minimum age in a census
Twenty as the minimum age for Levitical service
Thirty as the age for beginning a life's work

seealsos.comment: The ``thirtieth year'' may refer to Ezekiel's age.

children.title: Thirty as the minimum age for Levitical service

primaryrefs.comment: Forty days is a standard period, sometimes viewed as a time of preparation or testing before a major event.

secondaryrefs.comment: Jesus Christ fasted for forty days in the wilderness.

children.title: Forty years as a general term for a generation
children.precomment: God's anger against Israel in the wilderness:

children.title: The fiftieth year as the Year of Jubilee

primaryrefs.comment: The word ``jubilee'' refers to the liberation of slaves, rather than to a fixed period of time. The number 50 represents the year following seven periods of seven years, i.e., 49 years + 1.

children.title: Seventy people went down to Egypt
Seventy years as the human lifespan
numbers, hundreds and thousands
children.comment: The words ``hundreds'' and, especially, ``thousands'', often refer to large quantities in general; they are also used simply in a superlative sense.

children.title: A hundred in Jesus Christ's teaching
Hundreds and thousands as military units
God shows his love to thousands
God protects one believer amidst thousands of people
God helps one believer against a thousand
God allows thousands to be defeated
A thousand years
children.precomment: As a day to the Lord:

secondaryrefs.comment: the reign of Jesus Christ with believers for 1,000 years while Satan is restrained
666 is a symbol of total incompleteness
144,000 symbolises the perfect number of God's people.

children.title: God's people are compared to stars and sand
numbers, combinations
children.comment: Numbers may be combined for making a comparison. When they are combined in such a pattern as ``two or three'' the emphasis usually falls on the second figure.

children.title: Two or three as a small approximate number
Two and three in a climactic pattern
Three or four as a small approximate number
Three and four in a climactic pattern
Other examples of the climactic pattern
Comparative use of multiples of ten
Numerical contrast between Saul and David
numbers, fractions
children.comment: Mainly associated with divisions of the people and of property, and also with sacrificial offerings.

children.title: Thirds in the processes of judgment
A fifth in cases of restitution
Redeeming what is promised to God

primaryrefs.comment: The term ``tithe'' is the Old English word for ``one tenth''.

secondaryrefs.comment: teachers of the law and Pharisees

children.title: Sermon on the Mount
children.comment: A collection of Jesus Christ's teaching on the theme of discipleship. It deals with the righteousness required of disciples, the way they are to perform their religious duties, and the blessing and persecution they will know as followers of Christ. It can be seen as a manifesto setting out the nature of life in the kingdom of God.

cschildren.title: The setting of the Sermon on the Mount

primaryrefs.comment: Either Jesus Christ taught similar material in two different locations, as is common in preaching, or else Luke more specifically identifies that he taught on a level place or plateau on the mountainside.

cschildren.title: The teaching of the Sermon on the Mount

children.title: The blessings of being in the kingdom
Jesus Christ's disciples are to have a positive influence on the world
The relationship between Jesus Christ's message and the law
Jesus Christ's disciples are to exhibit a new depth of righteousness
The righteousness required of Jesus Christ disciples
children.precomment: Not only murder but also anger and broken relationships are wrong:

secondaryrefs.comment: faithfulness in marriage is called for
faithfulness in speech is called for
Retaliation must be abandoned, and enemies as well as neighbours must be loved.

children.title: Jesus Christ's disciples are to seek only God's approval in their religious duties
How religious duties are to be performed

seealsos.comment: Giving to the poor is to be done secretly
Prayer is not to become a public display
Fasting is to be done without show.

children.title: The kingdom is to be valued above material possessions
Jesus Christ's disciples are to avoid being judgmental
Jesus Christ's disciples should pray, confident of an answer
True disciples will obey Jesus Christ teaching

cschildren.title: Characteristics of Jesus Christ's teaching in the Sermon on the Mount

children.title: symbols
children.comment: Objects, actions or creatures that have a deeper significance and are so understood by those who see them or use them.

cschildren.title: Symbolic objects

children.title: The rainbow: a symbol of God's covenant
A stairway: a symbol of the way to God
Thunder, lightning, cloud and smoke: symbols of God's majesty
Thunder: a symbol of God's voice
Trumpets: a symbol of God speaking
The pillar of cloud and fire: a symbol of guidance
A throne:  a symbol of God's glory
Dry bones: a symbol of spiritual death
White hair: a symbol of wisdom
The wind: a symbol of the Holy Spirit
Fire: a symbol of the Holy Spirit
Stars and lampstands: symbols of God's ministers
A signet ring: a symbol of authority
A sceptre: a symbol of God's rule
The capstone: a symbol of pre-eminence
A rock: a symbol of stability
The human body: a symbol of interdependence
Grass: a symbol of human frailty

cschildren.title: Symbolic creatures

children.title: The serpent: a symbol of Satan's subtlety
Locusts: a symbol of God's judgment
A dove: a symbol of the Holy Spirit
A lamb: a symbol of Jesus Christ's sacrifice

cschildren.title: Symbolic actions

children.title: Breaking a jar: a symbol of the destruction of Jerusalem
The cursing of a fig-tree: a symbol of judgment
Washing hands: a symbol of innocence
Being thirsty: a symbol of spiritual need
Baptism: a symbol of salvation in Jesus Christ
The Lord's Supper: a symbol of union with Christ
Anointing: a symbol of empowering by God's Spirit
Harvesting: a symbol of judgment day
Tearing garments: a symbol of anger and sorrow
Shaking off dust: a symbol of rejection
Sitting in sackcloth and ashes: a symbol of repentance
Lifting of hands: a symbol of prayer
Covering the head: a symbol of submission

cschildren.title: Symbols expressing God's nature and character

children.title: God's face: a symbol of his presence
God's arm or hand: a symbol of his power
God's eyes: a symbol of his awareness
God's ear: a symbol of God listening
types
children.comment: An OT institution, person, place or event regarded as anticipating the person of Jesus Christ or some aspect of the Christian faith or life.

cschildren.title: OT foreshadowings of Jesus Christ
OT institutions as types

children.title: The Sabbath:  Jesus Christ's finished work
Marriage:  Jesus Christ's union with his people

seealsos.comment: Adam may be viewed as a figure of Jesus Christ, and Eve, of the church, formed in Christ, loved and united with him

children.title: The tabernacle: Jesus Christ's coming among his people

primaryrefs.comment: The context shows that ``The Word'' is Jesus Christ; ``made his dwelling'' involves the idea of pitching a tent and reflects the tabernacle which was pitched among the Israelites and filled with God's glory; so Christ has pitched his tent among his people and revealed his glory.

children.title: The tabernacle: the way to God
The high priesthood: Jesus Christ as intercessor

seealsos.comment: Jesus Christ, the great high priest, is both human and divine
Note the contrast between the many OT sacrifices and Jesus Christ's once-for-all offering of himself.

children.title: The priesthood: Christian worship and service

seealsos.comment: Hands laid on the head of the sacrifice symbolised the transfer of guilt and its consequences to another. A perfect animal was required

children.title: The day of atonement: Jesus Christ as sin-bearer

primaryrefs.comment: ``Redemption'' and ``ransom'' both involve buying back that which has been lost.

seealsos.comment: Blood is the ransom price for the forgiveness of sin

cschildren.title: OT places as types

children.title: The promised land: rest in Christ

primaryrefs.comment: Some take Babylon to represent the world, some the apostate church, some a city.

cschildren.title: OT people as types

children.title: Adam: Jesus Christ as the head of his people

seealsos.comment: Just as Adam was the representative of all humanity in the fall, so Jesus Christ is the representative of all who inherit salvation.

children.title: Abraham: justifying faith in Jesus Christ
Sarah and Hagar: grace and law
David: Jesus Christ as king, shepherd and sufferer
Solomon: Jesus Christ as wise ruler

cschildren.title: OT events as types

children.title: Abraham offering Isaac: God giving his Son
Crossing the Red Sea: Christian commitment
Water from a rock: Jesus Christ's provision
The bronze snake: Jesus Christ, the object of faith
word of God
children.comment: The utterances of God, especially as revealed in Scripture. This may take the form of commands or promises. The term can also refer to Jesus Christ as the incarnate Word of God.

cschildren.title: The word of God revealed as law

children.title: God has made his commands and requirements known
God's law is to be obeyed
Examples of disobedience and its consequences

cschildren.title: The word of God as prophecy

children.title: The prophets spoke the words of God

primaryrefs.comment: God's prophetic word came to Israel with varying frequency.

children.title: Prophetic introductory formulae
children.precomment: ``The word of the LORD came to ...'':

children.title: The word ``against'' a people, indicating judgment
True prophecy is inspired by God
A true prophet hears from God
The prophetic word is to be heeded

cschildren.title: The word of God as Scripture

children.title: Scripture is the written word of God
NT writings are classified as Scripture
The foundational importance of Scripture
children.precomment: It must not be distorted or changed:

secondaryrefs.comment: It sets the limit of authoritative doctrine.

cschildren.title: Jesus Christ as the incarnate Word of God

children.title: Jesus Christ is God in the flesh
Jesus Christ speaks the Father's words
Jesus Christ's words have sovereign power

cschildren.title: The gospel as the word of God

children.title: It was preached by Jesus Christ
It was preached by the first Christians
It leads to numerical and spiritual growth within the church

secondaryrefs.comment: Paul stresses that the preached word is not merely a verbal message but a dynamic power which achieves things.

cschildren.title: Descriptions of God's word

secondaryrefs.comment: It is exalted above all things
It is the sword of the Spirit

cschildren.title: Comparisons of the word of God with everyday things
The word of God has power

primaryrefs.comment: The Hebrew for ``word'' can also mean ``action'' or ``deed''. This indicates that God's word is active.

children.title: It governs and maintains the created order

secondaryrefs.comment: ``the word of God and prayer'' probably means ``scriptural prayer''; i.e., on the basis of scriptural teaching the believer offers thanksgiving and prayer.

children.title: It brings about the growth of the kingdom of God
